Explanation:
$T$ is an interval of real line. 
Every $t$ represents an instant of time. 
the relation $\leq$ that orders $T$ means “earlier than or simultaneous with.”

$E^{3}$ is 3-dimensional  Euclidean space. 
$E^{3}$ represents (maps) ordinary space.

Independent: SR 4 E3R: A manifold mapping local space
Explanation:
$E^{3}$ is a tridimensional Euclidean space with inner product. 
$E^{3}$ represents ordinary space relative to (a”as seen from” any given $i\subset I$).

$M^{3}$ is a 3-dimensional  differentiable manifold. 
$M^{3}$ represents physical space.

$M^{4}$ is 4-dimensional differentiable manifold of class $C^{2}$. 
For every point $x\subset M^{4}$, there exists a neighborhood of $x$ over which a local coordinate system can be given (defined).
the function s fmu that map neighboring coordinate sets onto one another are continuous and have continuous derivatives up to 2nd order in $M^{4}$. 
$M^{4}$ represents physical space.

Independent: SR 5 tR:  The range of the local time function
Explanation:
$T$ is an interval of the real line. 
$T$ is the range of the time function satisfying the axioms of the local time theory. 
Every $t\subset T$ represents an instant of t-time.
For every $i$, $i'\in I$, the associated cotimes are such that $\frac{\partial X_{0}}{\partial X'_{0}}$ exists and is positive.

$\Sigma$ is a nonempty denumerable set. 
Every $\Sigma$ is a particle.

$\Sigma$ is a nonempty denumerable set. 
Every $\Sigma$ is a body.

$\Phi$ is a nonempty set. 
Every $\Phi$ is an e.m. field.

$\Sigma$ is a nonempty set. 
Every $\Sigma$ is a charged body.

$\Sigma$ is a nonempty set. 
Every $\Sigma$ represents a gravitational field.

Independent: GR 1.2 Physical entities other than gravitational fields
Explanation:
$\overline{\Sigma}$ is a nonempty set disjoint from sigma. 
Every $\overline{\Sigma}$ represents a physical system other than  a gravitation field.

$\Sigma\neq\emptyset$. 
Every $\sigma\subset\Sigma$ represents a physical system.

$S\neq\emptyset$ and $S\subset\Sigma$. 
Every $s\in S$ represents an electromagnetic signal.

Independent: PM 2.2 Postulate: Once a particle always a particle
Explanation:
For any two different $t$, $t'\in T$, ir $\sigma\in\Sigma$ at $t$, then $\sigma\subset\Sigma$ at $t’$. 
This postulate is needed in order to warrant that predictions and retrodictions calculated for a $Sigma$ on laws of motion and initial conditions will still refer to $Sigma$.

$X$ is continuous and bounded for every $\beta$, $k$, and $t$. 
$X(\beta,k,t)$ represents the place (location) of the particle $\pi$ of the body $\sigma$, relative to the frame $k$ at the instant $t$.

$\left\{ X\right\} $ is a nonempty family of functions. 
Every $X\in\left\{ X\right\} $ is a function from $\Sigma\times I\times T$ to $R^{3}$. 
$X\left(\sigma,i,t\right)$ represents the position of a point system $\sigma\subset\Sigma$, referred to the frame $\tau$, at the instant $t$ relative to $\tau$. 
For every point event there exists a septuple $\left\langle \sigma,s,\tau,X_{0},X_{1},X_{2},X_{3}\right\rangle \hat{=}$ event.

Independent: GR 4.2  {XGR}: Position of a point system
Explanation:
For every $i=1,2,3$, $\left\{ X_{i}\right\} $ is a nonempty family of functions. 
Every $X_{i}\in\left\{ X_{i}\right\} $ is a function from $\overline{\Sigma}\times K\times T$ to $\mathbb{R}$, continuous w.r.t. $t$. 
$X(\bar{\sigma},k,t)$ represents the position of a point system $\bar{\sigma}\in\bar{\Sigma}$, referred to $k$, at the instant $t$ relative to $k$.

Independent: PM 2.3, CM 2.1, GR 4.1 Physical reference frames
Explanation:
$K$ is a nonempty denumerable set. 
Every $k$ is a rigid system of corpuscles at least four of which lie on the vertices of a regular trihedral. 
For every $k$ there exists a Cartesian system of axes $e=\left\langle e_{1},e_{2}.e_{3}\right\rangle $ such that $e\hat{=}k$. 
No $k$ interacts with any $\sigma\subset\Sigma$ that is not a part of $k$. 
The configuration of every $k\in K$ is time-independent.

$I\neq\emptyset\land I\subset\Sigma-S$. 
Every $i\in I$ is an inertial reference frame. 
For every $i\in I$ there is a basis $e=\left\langle e_{1},e_{2}.e_{3}\right\rangle $ such that $e\hat{=}i$.

Independent: PM 2.5 Postulate: Position and velocity values uniquely identify a particle
Explanation:
For any two $\sigma,\sigma'\in\Sigma$ and every $k\in K$ and every $t’\in T$, if $X\left(\sigma,t,k\right)=X\left(\sigma',t,k\right)$ and $\dot{X}\left(\sigma,t,k\right)=\dot{X}\left(\sigma',t,k\right)$, then $\sigma=\sigma’$.
In words: the position and velocity values uniquely identify (characterize) a particle. Coordinates alone are insufficient for this: thus two different particles may be at the same place at the instant of collision but then they will have different (vector) velocities.

$M$ is a function from $\Sigma$ to the set $\mathbb{R^{+}}$ of nonnegative reals. 
The value of $M$ at $\sigma,\in\Sigma$ represents the mass (inertia) of $\sigma$.

Independent: PM 3.2 The mass of a system of point particles equals the sum of the partial masses
Explanation: If $\sigma_{i}\in\Sigma$ for every finite $i\in N$, then $M\left(\underset{i}{\dot{\sum}}\sigma_{i}\right)=\underset{i}{\sum}M(\sigma_{i})$.

Every $F^{e}\in\left\{ F^{e}\right\}$ is a real valued vector on $\Sigma\times K\times E^{3}\times T$. 
The value of $F^{e}$ at any given 6-ple $\left\langle \sigma,k,x,t\right\rangle $ represents the external force acting on $\sigma$, relative to the frame $k$, at the place $x$ and the instant $t$.

Every $F^{i}\in\left\{ F^{i}\right\} $ is a real valued vector on $\Sigma\times\Sigma\times K\times E^{3}\times T$. 
The value of $F^{i}$ at any given 7-ple $\left\langle \sigma,\sigma',k,x,t\right\rangle $ represents the force extended by $\sigma'$ on $sigma$ relative to $k$ at $x$ and $t$.

For every $\sigma,\sigma'\in\Sigma$, every $t\in T$, every $F^{e}\in\left\{ F^{e}\right\} and every $F^{i}\in\left\{ F^{i}\right\}, there is at least one $k\in K$ such that 
$\dot{p}(\sigma,t,k)=F^{e}(\sigma,t,k)+\underset{\sigma’\neq\sigma}{\sum}F^{i}(\sigma,\sigma’,t,k)$ 
and
$F^{i}(\sigma,\sigma’,t,k)=-F^{i}(\sigma',\sigma,t,k)$.

For every $X\in\left\{ X\right\}$, every $b\in\beta$ and every $t\in T$, the map $X:b\rightarrow C$ is 1:1, onto and continuous.
For every $X\in\left\{ X\right\}$, every $b\in\beta$ and every $t\in T$ the image $C=X(b,t)$ of $b$ under $X$ is a compact set with a piecewise continuous boundary $\partial X(b,t)$.
For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$ and $t\in T$ there exists an $X\in\left\{ X\right\} $ such that the image $X(b,t)$ of $b$ under $X$ represents the place occupied by the body sigma represented by $b$.

Every $\varrho\in\left\{ \varrho\right\} $ is a bounded and continuous function from $\beta$ to the set of nonnegative reals. 
If $b\hat{=}\sigma$, then $\varrho(b,x,t)$ represents the mass density of $\varrho$ at $x$,$t$.

For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$, if $b\hat{=}\sigma$ and $C$ is the image of $b$ under $X$, then $M$ is a Continuous function of the volume (Lebesgue measure) $\mu(b,t)$ of $b$ at $t$. 
b) For any two distinct $\sigma,\sigma'\in\Sigma$, if $b\hat{=}\sigma$ and $b’\hat{=}\sigma’$, and $b\cup b'\hat{=}\sigma+\sigma'$, then $M(b\cup b')=M(b)+M(b')$.
c) If $b\hat{=}c$, then $M(b)$ represents the mass of $\sigma$.

For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$, if $b\hat{=}\sigma$ and $C=X(b,t)$ and $C’ =X’(b)$ are two different configurations of $\sigma$ at a given time $t$, then the corresponding masses are the same: $M(\sigma)=\underset{X(b)}{\int}d^{3}x\varrho_{X}=\underset{X'(b)}{\int}d^{3}x\varrho_{X'}$

$\left\{ \rho\right\} $ is a nonempty family of functions. 
Every $\rho$ is a scalar valued function from $\beta\times M^{3}\times T$ to $\mathbb{R}$. 
If $b\hat{=}\sigma$, then $\rho(b,x,t)$ represents the charge density of $\rho$ at $x$,$t$.

$\left\{ \beta\right\} $ is a nonempty family of point sets. 
Every $b\in B$ is a 3-dimensional differentiable manifold. 
For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$ there exists a $b\in\beta$ such that $b\hat{=}\sigma$ pointwise.

$\left\{ \beta\right\} $ is a nonempty family of point sets. 
Every $b\in\beta$ is a 3-dimensional differentiable manifold. 
For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$ there exists a $b\in\beta$ such that $b\hat{=}\sigma$ pointwise.

$\left\{ E\right\} $ is a nonempty family of fields. 
Every $E\in\left\{ E\right\} $ is a real and vector valued function of $\Phi\times M^{3}\times T$. 
$E(\phi,x,t)$ represents the intensity of the electric component of $\phi$ at $x$,$t$.

Every $\left\{ B\right\} $ is a non empty family of fields. Every $B\in\left\{ B\right\} $ real pseudovector valued function on  $\Phi\times M^{3}\times T$. 
$B(\phi,x,t)$ represents the intensity of the magnetic component of $\phi$ at $x$,$t$.
$E$ and $B$ drop off with distance at least as fast as $\frac{1}{r}$.

Independent: CEM 1.9 Magnitude of the speed of e.m. signals in vacuum
Explanation:
$c$ is a positive real number such that $\left[d\right]=LT^{-1}$. 
SR 7
Every $s\in S$ propagates in vacuum, relative to any $i\in I$, with uniform rectilinear motion at the speed $c$.

Let $X'=a+QX$, with $a$ and $Q$ functions of time, represent a change of frame. Then 
If $V$ is a vector referring to $\pi\dot{\in}\sigma\in\Sigma$, which upon a change of frame becomes $V’=QV$, then $V’$ and $V$ refer to the same physical situation. 
If $S$ is a 2nd rank tensor referring to $\pi\dot{\in}\sigma\in\Sigma$, which upon a change of frame becomes $S'=QS\tilde{Q}$, where $\tilde{Q}$ is the transposed of $Q$, then $S’$ and $S$ refer to the same physical situation.

Independent: PM 2.4 Events and trayectory of motion
Explanation:
For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$, and every $k\in K$, every $X\in\left\{ X\right\} $ is a continuous and real valued function from $T$ to $E^{3}$. 
For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$ and every  $k\in K$, $\dot{X}$ is a piece-wise continuous and real valued function from $T$ to $E^{3}$. 
$X(\sigma,k,t)$ represents the position of $\sigma$, relative to the frame $k$ at the instant $t$. 
Every quintuple $\left\langle \sigma,X_{1},X_{2},X_{3},t\right\rangle $ represents an event. 
For any given $\sigma\in\Sigma $ and any given $k\in K$, the set $\left\{ X(\sigma,k,t)\mid t\in T\right\} $represents a trajectory (motion) of $\sigma$.

The derivatives $\dot{X}$ and $\ddot{X}$ exist and are bounded for every $X\in\left\{ X\right\} $, every $\beta\in b$, every $k\in K$ and every $t\in T$. 
If $\beta\hat{=}\pi$ and $\pi\dot{\in}\sigma$, then $\dot{X}(\beta,k,t)$ and $\ddot{X}(\beta,k,t)$ represent the velocity and the acceleration respectively of the particle $\pi$ in the body $\sigma$ relative to the frame at time $t$.

Every $f_{b}\in\left\{ f_{b}\right\} $ is a real and bounded vector field over $\beta\times K\times E^{3}\times T$. 
If $b\hat{=}\sigma$, then $f_{b}(b,k,x,t)$ represents the force per unit volume on the body $\sigma$.

Every $\mathrm{T\in\left\{ \mathrm{T}\right\} }$ is a real and bounded tensor field of valence (2,0) over $\beta\times K\times E^{3}\times T$. 
If $b\hat{=}\sigma$, and $beta\hat{=}\pi$, then $\mathrm{T(\beta,K,x,t)}$ represents the body stress at the particle $\pi\dot{\in}\sigma$.

Independent: CM 3.3 Law of balance of momentum
Explanation: For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$, $t\in T$, every $\varrho\in\left\{ \varrho\right\} $, every $f_{b}\in\left\{ f_{b}\right\} $ and every $\mathrm{T\in\left\{ \mathrm{T}\right\} }$, there exists a $k\in K$ such that $\dot{p}=F$,

Independent: CM 3.4 Law of moment of momentum
Explanation: For every $\sigma\in\Sigma$, every $t\in T$,every $\varrho\in\left\{ \varrho\right\} $, every $f_{b}\in\left\{ f_{b}\right\} $, and every $\mathrm{T\in\left\{ \mathrm{T}\right\} }$, there exists a $k\in K$ such that $\dot{L}=N$.

At any point $x\in M^{3}$ and any instant $t\in T$ for every field 
$varphi\in \Phi$ and every charged body 
$\sigma\in \Sigma$, there exists a 
$k\in K$ such that 
$\nabla\times E=-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial B}{\partial t}$,     $\nabla\cdot B=0$
$\nabla\times B=-\frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial E}{\partial t}+\frac{4\pi}{c}j$,   $\nabla\cdot E=4\pi\varrho$.

The force density exerted by an external field $\left\langle E,B\right\rangle \hat{=}\varphi\in\Phi$ on $\sigma\in \Sigma$ is 
$f=\rho\left(E+\frac{v}{c}\times B\right)$

When the constitutive tensor degenerates into $(\epsilon,\mu^{-1})$, the field equations become $
abla	imes E=- rac{1}{c} rac{\partial B}{\partial t}$, $
abla\cdot B=0$,
$
abla	imes H=- rac{1}{c} rac{\partial D}{\partial t}+ rac{4\pi}{c}j$,   $
abla\cdot D=4\piho$

All coordinate transformations in $M^{4}$ are bijective maps. 
The Jacobian of every coordinate transformation vanishes nowhere. 
Areas and volumes should not vanish upon coordinate transformations, for otherwise things themselves would appear to vanish by sheer paper and pencil operations.

For any point $x\in M^{4}$ there exists a neighborhood of $x$ over which a local coordinate system can be given such that $x^{0}$ is a (local) time coordinate and $x^{1}$, $x^{2}$ and $x^{3}$ are (local) spatial coordinates. 
[Roughly: the tangent space of $M^{4}$ at any $x\in M^{4}$ is spacetime.].

$\left\{ gight\} $ is a nonempty family of symmetric tensor fields, of valence (0,2), on $M^{4}$.
The components of $g$ and their first and second derivatives w.r.t. the $x^{\mu}$ are real valued and bounded in every $V\subset M^{4}$ with the possible exception of a proper subset of $V$. 
 $M^{4}$ is endowed with a metric $ds^{2}=g_{\mu
u}dx^{\mu}dx^{
u}$ with $\mu,
u=0,1,2,3$.

$g_{00}>0$ and $g_{ij}<0$ $(i,j, =1,2,3)$ everywhere.
$g_{ij}-(g_{0i}g_{0j}/g_{00})<0$ everywhere.
To ensure that $x^{0}$, or rather $(g_{00})^{\frac{1}{2}}\frac{x^{0}}{c}$, be a time coordinate and the others be space coordinates as required by GR 2.3.

The components of $g$ approach constant values as the $x^{i}(i=1,2,3)$ tend to infinity.
The metric tensor, which solves the field equations, should represent an isolated system. Outside every $V\subset M^{4}$, the asymptotic forms of the components of $g$ are those of outgoing spherical waves.
a) For every $\sigma\in \Sigma$ there exists a metric tensor $g$ whose associated metric affinity $\Gamma$ represents the strength of $\sigma$.

$\mathrm{T}$ is a contravariant symmetric tensor field on $V\subset M^{4}$.
$\mathrm{T}$ represents the energy, momentum and stress of all the systems $\bar{\sigma}\in\bar{\Sigma}$ in $V$.

Independent: GR 5.2 Tipification for components of T
Explanation:
The components of $\mathrm{T}$ are real valued functions of $\bar{\sigma}$, $k$, $X$ and $t$.
The components of $\mathrm{T}$ vanish outside $V$.

$\kappa$ is a positive real number with dimension $L^{-1}M^{-1}T^{2}$.
$\kappa$ represents the coupling of $\sigma$ with $\bar{\sigma}$.

For every $x\in V$, every $\sigma\in\Sigma$, every $\bar{\sigma}\in\bar{\Sigma}$ and every $\mathrm{T\in\left\{ \mathrm{T}\right\} }$, there is a $g\in\{g\}$ such that 
$G=\kappa\mathrm{T}$.
Two solutions of Einsteins’s equation which can be transformed into one another by an admissible coordinate transformation refer to the same field.
